comment._content: I always think of this film when I see pictures of little railway stations! - www.youtube.com/watch?v=M1lxDjd_fi8

comment.author: 34305619@N06
comment._content: pity the station house isn't included -before the current building got built all around it!

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: This must be the same signalman as in www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/7076908151 The weird contraption (technical term) looks like a staff exchange machine.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/14302637@N08] I was just adding a note on that device.  My father who was a train guard for many years also caught the staff but he may have been a backup in case the driver or fireman (if there was one) missed it.  Sometimes they were a large item like a baton and more often they were approx six inches long and carried in a pouch attached to a ring through which the catcher hooked his arm.

comment.author: 32428096@N05
comment._content:
Wow! What a difference to today's station.

This is now a typical modern comuter station with the ticketing office, etc built raised above the tracks towards the far (west) end. The skyline behind the engine is now dominated by apartments, and the white timber building long demolished. The other building partially hidden by the loco is a private residence afaik.

I am almost certain that is a 121-class loco as well.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content:
Lovely O'Dea capture. Yes the engine is another 121 Class loco, pity can't make out the number, yellow on grey can be tricky! 
Notice that also the snatcher on the side cab has been lowered to take the staff/token from the aforementioned apparatus on the platform. 
The photo also shows very clearly the ground point rodding laid between the tracks, which stop opposite the signal cabin from where everything was operated from.

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/32428096@N05] 

I know the view you describe, there would have been very few people living around Leixlip at that particular time. Maybe you could take a shot and show the two comparisons, then & now?
Just a suggestion.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/photoken04] I'm just looking at my own photos also, and remarkably the tall railway style telegraph pole is still in situ at the station.

comment._content: No apology necessary... I find this photo very interesting with nice details!!!

comment._content: Is it Confey or Louise Bridge?

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/joefuz] Louise Bridge, although it was simply Leixlip in those days.

comment.author: 31536722@N00
comment._content:
If you describe this photo as 'not great' I wouldn't like to see one of your bad ones! Every one of them is brilliant and a glimpse into a world that's disappeared. Wasn't it a shame that so many of our rail lines were shut down?

Keep up the fine work.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/16489083@N05] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/an_solas] I hadn't meant any disrespect to James O'Dea's photo in the sense of subject matter, just that this one wasn't as sharp in focus as they usually are.
